awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Fluid Mechanics with Analysis using Computations and Experiments (FM-ACE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This three year renewal Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program, Fluid Mechanics with Analysis using Computations and Experiments (FM-ACE), at the University of Alabama Tuscaloosa, will engage and mentor a diverse cohort of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups with limited access to research facilities in exciting and emerging areas related to fluid mechanics. The field of fluid mechanics is unique in its ability to be visually captivating, making it an excellent area of research for motivating students to pursue graduate study. It is also multidisciplinary in nature as a wide range of engineering disciplines require varying depths of knowledge in fluid mechanics. While many basic aspects of fluid mechanics are well understood, it is still an engaging field of study where innovation and exciting discoveries are actively taking place; this is greatly in part due to the technological advances in experimental and computational capabilities over the last 20 years such as high speed imaging, advanced laser diagnostics and powerful computing. A major aim of this site is to diversify and increase the number of American engineers who pursue a graduate education and enter the engineering work force to perform cutting edge research leading to technological innovation in areas of public and national defense interest, thereby furthering our country's prosperity. 

The University of Alabama Tuscaloosa will host 10 undergraduate students over 10 summer weeks in exciting and emerging areas related to fluid mechanics with an end goal of presenting their research the following November at the American Physical Society Division of Fluid Dynamics (APS DFD) conference. This component of the program acts as an important follow-through mechanism to further encourage REU participants to pursue graduate studies and contributes to the success of the site by motivating both the student and mentors to obtain quality research results. Other important objectives include providing a structure wherein research and technical communication skills are cultivated. This site involves basic and applied research in fluid mechanics across a range of engineering disciplines as well as the training of undergraduate students in state-of-the-art laboratory environments. Students will contribute to projects that include, as a sampling, Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) investigations of bio-inspired boundary layer control mechanisms, combustion studies using a color schlieren system, and computational aeroacoustics.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates Site in Fluid Mechanics at The University of Alabama mentored 120 undergraduate researchers over 13 summers (2008-2019,2021) in exciting and emerging areas related to fluid mechanics with an end goal of presenting their research at a national conference. With respect to intellectual merit, this site involved basic and applied research in fluid mechanics across a range of engineering disciplines as well as the training of undergraduate students in state-of-the-art laboratory environments. Students contributed to projects that included, as a sampling, Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) investigations of bio-inspired boundary layer control mechanisms, combustion studies using a color schlieren system, and computational aeroacoustics. The need for cross-disciplinary communication was emphasized to the students as essential to foster maximum growth of knowledge in a field of research and, in particular, in the area of fluid mechanics. This program provided a structured plan for each student to present their work at the American Physical Society Division of Fluid Dynamics (APS DFD) Meeting held each fall. This aspect to the program makes it unique, genuinely demonstrating the goal of exposing undergraduate students to all phases of a rewarding research experience. Assessment of the program has resulted in continuous improvement to the site and, especially, to the technical seminars and communication skills workshops. A primary goal was to encourage and prepare these students to pursue graduate studies, and overall this goal was successfully achieved according to student feedback.

One broader impact goal of the program included enhancing and diversifying the pool of students considering a research career in engineering. The program incorporated an aggressive recruitment plan for attracting talented female and other underrepresented groups.  The major outcomes include:

 -- Over 50% participants were from underrepresented groups, primarily women?a target demographic.

--  99% of the participants participated in the annual APS Fluids meeting?a specific goal of the Site.  Beyond this there resulted more than 30 conference presentations/papers and/or journal papers from the summer research performed.

--  Communication skills (oral and written) show marked improvement as indicated by the students via follow-up questionnaires and their success in presenting at the APS meeting. Workshops and mechanisms to improve these skills (abstract preparation, technical writing, poster preparation, elevator talk, and three-minute video) are lauded by the participants.

--  At least 2/3 attended graduate school after completing their undergraduate degree. Schools attended include MIT, Caltech, Stanford, GA Tech, Penn State and University of Michigan among others.

The program not only advanced knowledge in new research areas within fluid mechanics, but also trained a group of diverse and highly-educated engineering researchers that have entered into the US workforce.
